Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: I was scrubbing the kitchen floor, the scent of lemon cleaner sharp in the air, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced at the message: a young couple from the congregation, asking if I could officiate their wedding next summer. My mind raced—this was the kind of moment I cherished as a rabbi, guiding people through sacred milestones. But as I looked around, I saw the dust gathering on the baseboards, the streaks on the windows, the crumbs under the table. The house was never quite clean enough, and I felt the weight of that expectation pressing on me. I knew I should respond to the couple quickly, offer warmth and reassurance, but the mop in my hand reminded me of the standards I set for myself here, too. My heart tugged in two directions: the sacred duty to my community, and the relentless, everyday duty to keep this home spotless. I stood there, phone in one hand, mop in the other, feeling the tension coil inside me, unsure which role to answer first.
